awd_abstract_narration:
Mammalian synthetic biology is the design of genetic devices that enables the study and control of biological processes in mammalian cells to provide the tools and design strategies to accelerate the advancement of various therapies; therefore, many of the technologies being developed will be useful for eventual medical use in the long term. The 2023 International Mammalian Synthetic Biology Workshop (mSBW) will bring together leaders in synthetic biology with experts from other relevant fields to highlight and inspire cutting-edge synthetic biology and cellular research. The program features talks on foundational technologies, reporters and recorders, circuits and dynamics, regenerative medicine and organoids, and immunoengineering that encourages the participation of students in order to train a new generation of engineers. This research positively impacts society by helping us to better understand and diagnose diseases, more rapidly discover effective therapeutics and develop precision medicine for individuals.  By focusing on mammalian synthetic biology across a broad range of applications, the meeting creates a unique environment to gather researchers with varying expertise, skillsets and levels of experience. This allows for the exchange of ideas, knowledge and opportunities for collaboration between people who rarely have the opportunity to interact. Funding for the conference will also support the attendance of underrepresented groups in engineering. 

The workshop will emphasize novel computational tools/methods to aid in predicting and quantitatively studying system behavior. The advances in fundamental science, engineering techniques, and computation models will be critical for the development of medicinal products in the long term as it will be useful for improving understanding, monitoring, and treatment of disease. The workshop will contain five technical sessions: (1) Foundational advances, (2) Applications in stem cells, (3) Immunotherapy and cell therapy, (4) Gene regulation, (5) Sensors and multi-input logic. The workshop will also host several Q&A discussions, networking breaks, as well as poster sessions that allow students to present their work. It is our hope that the various networking opportunities will give the attendees the ability to discuss the state-of-the-art technology being presented, and that the discussions will lead to potential collaborations that may accelerate development in the field.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Conference: 2023 Mammalian Synthetic Biology Workshop

Project Outcomes Report
Award 2330030

 

The 2023 Mammalian Synthetic Biology Workshop (mSBW) took place June 22-23 at the Holiday Inn San Jose-Silicon Valley in San Jose, California. The event gathered leaders in synthetic biology and experts from other relevant fields to highlight and inspire cutting-edge synthetic biology research, emphasizing both basic and applied science. Workshop topics included:

  • Foundational Technologies
  • Genome Architecture (Genetic/Epigenetic Engineering)
  • Towards Translation
  • Regenerative Medicine & Organoids
  • Immunoengineering

 

This conference was the first time mSBW took place in the United States since Covid. Gathering 190 attendees, mSBW reestablished itself as a critical event in the community. Keynotes and invited talks from current and rising mammalian synthetic biology leaders allowed the audience to learn about the latest research, methodologies and best practices. Poster sessions provided trainees and early career professionals with an opportunity to present and receive feedback on their work. Networking events offered time for informal discussions to develop new connections and foster collaboration.

Conference speakers included:

  • Caleb Bashor, Rice University
  • Ami Bhatt, Stanford University
  • Francesca Ceroni, Imperial College London
  • Emma Chory, Duke University
  • Rhima Coleman, University of Michigan
  • Scott Coyle, University of Wisconsin-Madison
  • Zibo Chen, Westlake University
  • Kyle Daniels, Stanford University
  • Farshid Guilak, Washington University
  • Theresa Loveless, Rice University
  • Emma Lundberg, Stanford University
  • John Ngo, Boston University
  • Jamie Spangler, Johns Hopkins University
  • Elizabeth Wayne, Carnegie Mellon University
  • Peter Zandstra, University of British Columbia
  • Xin Zhou, Dana-Farber Cancer Institute

Since its inception, mSBW has focused on inclusivity, aiming to be an affordable event for students, post-docs and early career faculty members. Offering registration rates below other comparable events makes it easier for people just starting their careers to be involved. It is particularly important for those early in their careers to attend mSBW, establishing their community and capitalizing on career development opportunities that can only be realized through in-person interactions.

Offering low registration rates has become more challenging over the past few years, due to increased venue and service costs. NSF support allowed mSBW to maintain its low registration rates. This resulted in over 90 U.S.-based students/post-docs and over 20 U.S.-based assistant professors receiving subsidized registration. Additionally, of attendees who responded, 49% were from a demographic defined by the NSF as a historically underrepresented group in STEM. This numbers show the impact that the NSF’s registration support can have on engaging trainees, early career professionals and underrepresented groups in conferences aimed at learning and career development opportunities.

 


Last Modified: 09/16/2024
Modified by: Evan Flach
